content.title: Multiple Myeloma
content.summary: Multiple myeloma (MM) is a malignant plasma cell neoplasm characterized by clonal bone marrow plasma cells producing monoclonal immunoglobulin (M-protein). It causes end-organ damage (CRAB: Calcium elevation, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone disease). Treatment involves triplet regimens (proteasome inhibitor + IMiD + steroid) and autologous stem cell transplant in eligible patients.
key_points: Definition: ≥10% clonal bone marrow plasma cells OR biopsy-proven plasmacytoma + myeloma-defining event
CRAB criteria: Calcium >11, Renal (Cr >2), Anemia (Hgb <10), Bone lesions
SLiM criteria: 60% plasma cells, involved/uninvolved FLC ratio ≥100, >1 focal lesion on MRI
M-protein: SPEP + SFLC for diagnosis and monitoring
Treatment: VRd (bortezomib-lenalidomide-dex) → ASCT if eligible; daratumumab increasingly first-line
content.statement: Multiple myeloma is a clonal plasma cell malignancy producing monoclonal immunoglobulin with end-organ damage (CRAB) diagnosed by bone marrow biopsy and serum/urine protein electrophoresis, treated with proteasome inhibitor-based triplet regimens and autologous stem cell transplant in eligible patients.

explanation.intuition: Plasma cells are antibody factories. In myeloma, a single plasma cell clone multiplies uncontrollably, crowding the bone marrow (→anemia), destroying bone (→fractures, hypercalcemia), and producing excessive antibody protein that damages kidneys (→renal failure).
explanation.key_insight: The CRAB criteria identify symptomatic myeloma requiring treatment. The newer SLiM criteria identify high-risk 'smoldering' myeloma that should also be treated despite absent CRAB features because progression is imminent.
explanation.technical_details: M-protein is detected by SPEP (serum protein electrophoresis) as a monoclonal spike. Immunofixation identifies the heavy and light chain type (IgG kappa is most common). Free light chain assay is essential for light-chain-only myeloma. t(11;14), t(4;14), del(17p), and +1q are important cytogenetics.

definitions_glossary.multiple_myeloma: Clonal plasma cell neoplasm producing monoclonal immunoglobulin with end-organ damage
definitions_glossary.M_protein: Monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chain produced by myeloma cells
definitions_glossary.CRAB: Calcium, Renal, Anemia, Bone - end-organ damage criteria
definitions_glossary.SLiM: Sixty percent plasma cells, Light chain ratio ≥100, MRI lesions >1 - biomarkers of imminent progression
definitions_glossary.SPEP: Serum protein electrophoresis; detects monoclonal protein spike
definitions_glossary.SFLC: Serum free light chain assay; detects kappa or lambda light chains
definitions_glossary.proteasome_inhibitor: Drug class blocking proteasome (bortezomib, carfilzomib, ixazomib)
definitions_glossary.ASCT: Autologous stem cell transplant; consolidation after induction
definitions_glossary.MGUS: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance; precursor lesion
definitions_glossary.smoldering_myeloma: Clonal plasma cells with M-protein but no CRAB; watch or treat if SLiM
definitions_glossary.daratumumab: Anti-CD38 monoclonal antibody; increasingly first-line in myeloma

pathophysiology.mechanism: Clonal plasma cell proliferation → M-protein production → hyperviscosity, renal damage; bone destruction via osteoclast activation; bone marrow crowding → cytopenias

IMWG_2014.requirement: ≥10% clonal plasma cells OR plasmacytoma AND myeloma-defining event

workup: Skeletal survey or whole-body low-dose CT or PET-CT

differential_diagnosis: MGUS (M-protein <3 g/dL, <10% plasma cells, no CRAB)
Smoldering myeloma (≥10% plasma cells but no CRAB/SLiM)

induction.transplant_ineligible: VRd or Dara-Rd until progression; similar regimens, longer duration

transplant.ASCT: High-dose melphalan followed by autologous stem cell rescue; deepens response

definition.@value: A clonal plasma cell malignancy producing monoclonal immunoglobulin (M-protein) causing CRAB end-organ damage

learning_objectives: Apply CRAB and SLiM criteria for diagnosis
Interpret serum protein electrophoresis and free light chains
Select appropriate induction therapy based on transplant eligibility
clinical_pearls: Check SFLC even if SPEP normal - 15% are light-chain-only myeloma
Whole-body low-dose CT replacing skeletal survey - finds more lesions
High-risk cytogenetics: t(4;14), t(14;16), del(17p), +1q - shorter remissions
Daratumumab added to VRd (Dara-VRd) improves MRD negativity and PFS
